Pre-Game Insights: India have long been the benchmark ODI side but even they'll know Rashid and Gurbaz, on their day, can trip them up
India could likely take the attack to the quick bowlers
India may consider bringing in Shardul Thakur instead of Mohammed Shami
Rahmanullah Gurbaz will be relishing the conditions that this game will be played in
The re-laid surface in Delhi sports a generous smattering of grass
Teams batting first have won five of the last six ODIs here dating back to 2013
Chasing a par total shouldn't be overly difficult
Left-arm finger spinners have picked 21 wickets in the first six matches at 26.52 in this World Cup
Since his comeback, Bumrah has not gone wicketless even once and in the six ODIs he has conceded his runs at an average of 4.89 per over
Among members of India's squad, Jadeja has the most wickets in ODIs against Afghanistan [7 at 10.85] and in Delhi [9 at 20.77]
You know, we play better spin in the nets sessions. Rashid, Nabi, Noor and Mujeeb, we play them every day. So, I think our team is far better in playing spin bowling
India themselves got their second World Cup match win in their third tournament against the alpha of that era and never looked back

Miscellaneous Highlights: The pitch for this match will likely help the batters
The weather will be mostly cloudy for this 2023 World Cup game
The Feroz Shah Kotla was the scene where World Cup records tumbled with South Africa and Sri Lanka aggregating the highest match total and Aiden Markram amassing the fastest century
Rahmanullah Gurbaz is the quickest of the 13 Afghanistan batters to the mark of 1000 ODI runs
Their head-to-head record stands at: 05/03/2014: Dhaka - India won by 8 wickets, 25/09/2018: Dubai - Match Tied, 22/06/2019: Southampton - India won by 11 runs
When: India vs Afghanistan, October 11, 2023, 14:00 IST, Where: Arun Jaitley Stadium, New Delhi, What to expect: A warm day in the national capital and good conditions for batting
Others: Their first two ODI World Cups have come in Australia and England, conditions less suited to their spin-centric style
India have played a mere 29 matches between the last World Cup and this one, even going as far back as the first ODI they ever played, their tally only comes to 153
There are individual players in the Indian team that they'll face on Wednesday who have played almost twice as many matches
Experience is how batters learn when to go hard and when not to, when to just reduce risk, absorb the pressure and just trust that you can make up for lost ground
